awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Exploring the Design, Implementation, Operation Issues of Cellular IoT via Formal Analysis and Empirical Validation
awd_abstract_narration:
The Internet of Things is coming into our daily life. As the only large-scale wireless network infrastructure on a par with the Internet, the cellular network plays a critical role in interconnecting a variety of things. Connected cellular IoT (CIoT) devices are forecast to grow almost four-fold from 2015 (0.4 billion) to 2021 (1.5 billion). With the explosive growth of CIoT devices, any design defects of CIoT standards, implementation issues of CIoT devices, and operational slips of CIoT service operators could lead to devastating consequences on a global scale. This project seeks to conduct a full investigation of CIoT services from their design, implementation and operation perspectives. The successful completion of this project will not only contribute new techniques to identify design defects, implementation issues, and operational slips of CIoT services, but also facilitate the deployment of CIoT services and boost the CIoT economy in the U.S. The research findings may also influence the design of CIoT in the upcoming 5G wireless networks.

The proposed research has three key areas of technical contributions. First, it aims to develop a CIoT control-plane protocol verification tool based on formal methods, which identifies design defects of CIoT standards in terms of functional incorrectness, performance downgrade, and security issues. Second, it aims to develop a rigorous testing methodology for exploring the implementation issues and operational slips of CIoT practice, which covers CIoT conformance testing standards, CIoT practice, and feedbacks from SQA (Software Quality Assurance) experts in the CIoT industry. Third, it aims to develop an open-source CIoT test-bed including CIoT terminals and infrastructure to verify the possible design defects, implementation issues, and operational slips which are hardly to be validated in practice due to security, business, and other concerns. This CIoT test-bed will be released to the research community for future CIoT research. Besides technical contributions, the proposed project allows the researchers to integrate their research findings into both undergraduate and graduate curricula for both Electrical and Computer Engineering and Computer Science majors. Finally, this project will contribute to the nation's workforce by training students to obtain technical expertise in mobile systems, wireless networking, and formal methods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we have successfully developed new techniques, platforms, and testing datasets for exploring the design defects, implementation issues, and operational slips of cellular IoT services, benefiting the cellular IoT ecosystem in the U.S. First, we developed and released an open-source cellular IoT service testing platform (Sonica-PS) to support NB-IoT for the research community, in collaboration with the WiNG lab at UCLA. This platform allows researchers to further explore issues on commercial off-the-shelf IoT devices or operational cellular IoT infrastructure. Second, we successfully discovered many improper designs, implementations, and operations in operational IoT services. Some of them can even be exploited to launch various cyberattacks. For example, we found that the infrastructure could neither distinguish IoT devices from mobile devices nor confine IoT devices to their pre-defined use scenarios, allowing adversaries to disguise non-IoT devices as IoT devices to pay less without service downgrades and use IoT devices in unanticipated scenarios. Specifically, our study shows that adversaries can take advantage of carriers by paying 43.75-80% less for mobile services than non-IoT users pay. Moreover, an adversary could remotely identify the IP address and phone number assigned to a massive CIoT device by exploiting cellular IoT essential power-saving features and IMS voice services. The adversary could further launch denial-of-IoT-service attacks, raising an IoT data bill by $226 with less than 120 MB of spam traffic or increasing an IoT text bill at a rate of $5 per second. Third, we reported our findings to CIoT carriers and provided them with standard-compliant solutions that can be used immediately in practice. Fourth, we documented test procedures into a testing dataset designed to efficiently discover improper implementations and operations of operational IoT services, which can be used to examine various cellular IoT networks in different countries.

The project has resulted in 15 papers from top conferences and journals such as MobiCom, MobiSys, IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing, and IEEE/ACM Transactions on Networking. This project supported 6 PhD students and various undergraduate students. Two PhD students supported by this project are tenure-track assistant professors at universities, including Xinyu Lei at Michigan Technological University and Tian Xie at Utah State University. The research results have been incorporated into the graduate courses "Computer and Network Security" and the undergraduate course "Introduction to Computer Security," which are designed to efficiently discover improper implementations and operations of operational IoT services.

Modified by: Guan-Hua Tu
